Tables 2, 2 and 2 summarize our results on the three benchmark datasets.
We can observe that our method outperforms specially designed supervised methods for bias removal in VQA-CP; our model with UpDown is 1.1%percent1.11.1\% better than the supervised UpDown.
Under the ZSL setting for VQA-CP, our Encoder model is 6.1%percent6.16.1\% better than UpDown with patches, and 6.5%percent6.56.5\% better than UpDown with Object features, for VQA-v2: 6.2%percent6.26.2\%, 5.4%percent5.45.4\% respectively, and for GQA: 2.2%percent2.22.2\%, 3.0%percent3.03.0\% respectively.

S6.T4.caption: Table 4: Effect of different pre-training data sources on ZSL Validation split accuracies.
S6.T4.table:
Question Generation VQA-v2 VQA-CP GQA
Updn Template 26.2 25.7 11.6
Template + Para&Back 28.5 27.1 14.8
QA-SRL 31.1 33.8 18.9
All 41.4 40.2 31.1
Encoder Template 32.5 31.3 18.5
Template + Para&Back 34.8 33.6 23.6
QA-SRL 40.3 39.8 21.4
All 47.1 46.8 33.7
references:
In Table 4 we can observe the effect of different question generation techniques.
All models use spatial image patch features. QA-SRL based questions and the SWA-Loss contribute the most towards gains in performance, and the paraphrased questions provide larger linguistic variation.

S6.T5.caption: Table 5: Effect of the number of spatial patches on ZSL performance {3,5} implies division of the image into a 3x3 and 5x5 grid of patches.
S6.T5.table:
Patch Resolutions VQA-v2 VQA-CP GQA
UpDn {1} 18.8 19.7 11.3
{1, 3} 36.7 35.9 24.5
{1, 3, 5} 40.1 39.7 29.5
{1, 3, 5, 7} 41.4 40.2 31.1
{1, 3, 5, 7, 9} 39.8 38.4 29.3
Encoder {1} 26.4 27.7 15.3
{1, 3} 42.6 43.1 28.8
{1, 3, 5} 44.3 45.2 30.9
{1, 3, 5, 7} 47.1 46.8 33.7
{1, 3, 5, 7, 9} 46.2 45.4 31.2
references:
We study the effect of progressively increasing the number of spatial image patches (i.e., decreasing the patch size).
Table 5 shows that an optimum exists at grid-size of 7×7777\times 7 after which the addition of smaller patches is detrimental.
Similarly, only using patches of large size does not allow models to focus on specific image regions.
Thus a trade-off exists between global context and region-specific features.
Changing the feature extractor from ResNet-50 to ResNet-101 only results in a minor improvement of 0.01%percent0.010.01\% to 0.30%percent0.300.30\%.
Removing visual position embeddings has a significant effect on performance, with a drop of 4.60%percent4.604.60\% to 8.00%percent8.008.00\% in both ZSL and FSL settings.

S6.T6.caption: Table 6: Effect of different pre-training tasks on the ZSL performance for the Encoder model.
S6.T6.table:
Pre-Training Task VQA-v2 VQA-CP GQA
SWA 39.1 38.3 25.4
MLM+SWA 42.4 41.5 27.8
MQA+SWA 42.0 41.2 26.6
MLM+MQA+SWA 45.6 44.9 29.7
MLM+ITM+SWA 44.7 43.6 28.9
All 46.2 45.4 31.2
references:
Table 6 shows the effect of different pretraining tasks on the downstream zero-shot transfer VQA task.
We need the SWA task, as it is used to perform the zero-shot QA task.
The combination of MLM, MQA, and ITM, all of which need image understanding, shows improved performance on the downstream task, indicating better cross-modal representations.

A1.T8.caption: Table 8: The effect of using transformations (T) to create new Q-A pairs
A1.T8.table:
T Image Q A 𝐐𝐧𝐞𝐰subscript𝐐𝐧𝐞𝐰\mathbf{Q_{new}} 𝐀𝐧𝐞𝐰subscript𝐀𝐧𝐞𝐰\mathbf{A_{new}}
Negation Is this bread? yes Is this not bread no
What is the color of the woman’s shirt? black What is not the color of the woman’s shirt? white
Is there a boy? no Is there no boy? yes
Adversarial Who is sitting in the boat ? man Who is sitting in the dining table ? can’t say
How big is the plane ? large How big is the car ? size
How many puppies are on the bed ? two How many cats are on the bed? none
references:
Table 8 shows the use of two transformations (T): negation and adversarial words Gokhale et al. (2020b) two generate more sentences.
Thus the negation of Q𝑄Q or substitution of a word in Q𝑄Q with an adversarial word results in the new question-answer pair Qn​e​w,An​e​wsubscript𝑄𝑛𝑒𝑤subscript𝐴𝑛𝑒𝑤Q_{new},A_{new}.
To increase the linguistic diversity of the questions we use paraphrasing as shown in Table 11.

A2.T9.caption: Table 9: Distribution of samples by answer-type in our pre-training dataset and the VQA-CP evaludation dataset.
A2.T9.table:
Category VQA-CP (%) Pretraining (%)
Yes/No 41.86 50.18
Number 11.91 8.32
Other 46.23 41.45
references:
In Table 9, we compare the distribution per answer-type of our synthetically generated samples with the distribution in the VQA-CP-v2 Agrawal et al. (2018) dataset.
Since we use our synthetic samples as the pre-training data, and do not use VQA-CP samples for training in our zero-shot setup, this comparison displays the shift between the training (synthetic) and test (human annotated VQA-CP) datasets.

Hyper-Parameters Model
Batch Size 32-128

Hyperparameters and other training settings are given in Table 10.
